required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Smartphone Use and Neck Flexion Angle
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Smartphone Use on Neck Flexion Angle and Hand Grip Power Among Adolescence

brief_summary.textblock: Excessive smartphone use can disrupt your sleep, which can have a serious impact on your overall mental health. It can impact your memory, affect your ability to think clearly, and reduce your cognitive and learning skills. Encouraging self-absorption.

detailed_description.textblock:
Persistent failed attempts to use cell phone less often. Preoccupation with smartphone use. Turns to cell phone when experiencing unwanted feelings such as anxiety or depression. Excessive use characterized by loss of sense of time.
Nomophobia-an abbreviation of "no-mobile-phone-phobia"-is also called "cell phone addiction." Symptoms include: Experiencing anxiety or panic over losing your phone. Obsessively checking for missed calls, emails, and texts.

primary_outcome.time_frame: the neck flexion angle at day 0
the neck flexion angle at day 120

arm_group.arm_group_label: participants use smartphone less than 4 hours per day
arm_group.description: participants use smartphone less than 4 hours per day

arm_group.arm_group_label: participants use smartphone more than 4 hours per day
arm_group.description: participants use smartphone more than 4 hours per day

study_pop.textblock: healthy volunteers using smartphone less or more than 4 hours per day have not any signes of musculoskeletal problems

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- volunteers using smartphone less or more than 4 hours per day
Exclusion Criteria:
- low back pain surgeries affecting upper limps

overall_official.affiliation: South Valley University, Faculty of Physical Therapy
